CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus:
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
int NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus:
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
int NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure
if (CUR_ANIMATION == MALON_PENSIVE || CUR_HEADRAISE_ANIMATION == MALON_PENSIVE || CUR_ANIMATION == MALON_PENSIVE_HAPPY || CUR_HEADRAISE_ANIMATION == MALON_PENSIVE_HAPPY)
for (int i = HANDL; i <= ELBOWR; i++)
for (int i = HANDL; i <= ELBOWR; i++)
for (int i = HANDL; i <= ELBOWR; i++)
To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus:
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
int NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure

/* IDLE,        LAUGH,          TURN,           EVHOLD,             DESKSLAM,       SHOCK,              SMUG,               ANGRY,              FACEAWAY,           DESKSLAMMED         POINT               SERIOUS            */

{-1,            -1,             -1,             EVIDENCE2IDLE,      SLAM2IDLE,      SHOCK2IDLE,         -1,                 ANGRY2IDLE,         INTRO2IDLE,         SLAM2IDLE,          POINT2IDLE,         -1},                 // IDLE

{-1,            -1,             -1,             EVIDENCE2IDLE,      SLAM2IDLE,      SHOCK2IDLE,         -1,                 ANGRY2IDLE,         INTRO2IDLE,         SLAM2IDLE,          POINT2IDLE,         -1},                 // LAUGH

{IDLE2EVIDENCE, IDLE2EVIDENCE,  -1,             -1,                 SLAM2EVIDENCE,  SHOCK2EVIDENCE,     IDLE2EVIDENCE,      ANGRY2EVIDENCE,     -1,                 SLAM2EVIDENCE,      POINT2EVIDENCE,     IDLE2EVIDENCE},      // EVHOLD

{IDLE2SLAM,     IDLE2SLAM,      -1,             EVIDENCE2SLAM,      -1,             SHOCK2SLAM,         IDLE2SLAM,          ANGRY2SLAM,         -1,                 -1,                 POINT2SLAM,         IDLE2SLAM},          // DESKSLAM

{-1,            -1,             -1,             EVIDENCE2IDLE,      SLAM2IDLE,      SHOCK2IDLE,         -1,                 ANGRY2IDLE,         INTRO2IDLE,         SLAM2IDLE,          POINT2IDLE,         -1},                 // SMUG

{IDLE2ANGRY,    IDLE2ANGRY,     -1,             EVIDENCE2SLAM,      SLAM2ANGRY,     SHOCK2ANGRY,        IDLE2ANGRY,         -1,                 -1,                 SLAM2ANGRY,         POINT2ANGRY,        IDLE2ANGRY},         // ANGRY

{IDLE2POINT,    IDLE2POINT,     -1,             -1,                 SLAM2POINT,     SHOCK2POINT,        IDLE2POINT,         ANGRY2POINT,        -1,                 SLAM2POINT,         -1,                 IDLE2POINT},         // POINT

{-1,            -1,             -1,             EVIDENCE2IDLE,      SLAM2IDLE,      SHOCK2IDLE,         -1,                 ANGRY2IDLE,         -1,                 SLAM2IDLE,          POINT2IDLE,         -1},                 // SERIOUS
/* IDLE,        LAUGH,          TURN,           EVHOLD,         DESKSLAM,       SHOCK,          SMUG,        ANGRY,          FACEAWAY,           DESKSLAMMED ,     POINT,           SERIOUS   */
{IDLE,          LAUGH,          IDLE,           EVIDENCE,       SLAM,           SHOCK,          WAG,         ANGRY,          INTRO,              SLAM,             POINT,           IDLE};

/* IDLE,                    LAUGH,              TURN,                 EVHOLD,             DESKSLAM,               SHOCK,              SMUG,               ANGRY,                  FACEAWAY,               DESKSLAMMED,              POINT                   SERIOUS                 */

{DLIST_HEAD_DEFAULT,        DLIST_HEAD_GRIN,    DLIST_HEAD_SMIRK,     DLIST_HEAD_GRIN,    DLIST_HEAD_SERIOUS,     DLIST_HEAD_GASP,    DLIST_HEAD_SMIRK,   DLIST_HEAD_FUMING,      DLIST_HEAD_SERIOUS,     DLIST_HEAD_SERIOUS,       DLIST_HEAD_SMIRK,       DLIST_HEAD_SERIOUS};

/* IDLE,                    LAUGH,                     TURN,                       EVHOLD,                         DESKSLAM,                       SHOCK,                          SMUG,                             ANGRY,                     FACEAWAY,                           DESKSLAMMED,                        POINT                           SERIOUS             */

{STATE_DRAGMIRE_IDLE,       STATE_DRAGMIRE_IDLE,       STATE_DRAGMIRE_IDLE,        STATE_DRAGMIRE_EVHOLD,          STATE_DRAGMIRE_DESKSLAM,        STATE_DRAGMIRE_SHOCK,           STATE_DRAGMIRE_SMUG,              STATE_DRAGMIRE_ANGRY,      STATE_DRAGMIRE_FACEAWAY,            STATE_DRAGMIRE_DESKSLAMMED,         STATE_DRAGMIRE_POINT,           STATE_DRAGMIRE_SERIOUS};
/* IDLE,   LAUGH,    TURN,     EVHOLD,    DESKSLAM,  SHOCK,   SMUG,     ANGRY,   FACEAWAY,  DESKSLAMMED,   POINT,       SERIOUS     */
/* IDLE,   LAUGH,    TURN,     EVHOLD,    DESKSLAM,  SHOCK,   SMUG,     ANGRY,   FACEAWAY,  DESKSLAMMED,   POINT        SERIOUS     */
/* IDLE,   LAUGH,    TURN,     EVHOLD,    DESKSLAM,  SHOCK,   SMUG,     ANGRY,   FACEAWAY,  DESKSLAMMED,   POINT        SERIOUS     */
/* 0x000 */ Vec3f root;                              // root position along the collar
/* 0x00C */ Vec3f joints[GANON_MANT_NUM_JOINTS];     // "joints" for deforming the cloak, stemming from root and propagating down the cloak
/* 0x090 */ Vec3f rotations[GANON_MANT_NUM_JOINTS];  // normal vector rotations, x and y only
/* 0x120 */ Vec3f velocities[GANON_MANT_NUM_JOINTS]; // velocities calculated as differences in position from last update
/* 0x1B0 */ u8 torn[GANON_MANT_NUM_JOINTS];          // guess: whether the joint is torn?
/* 0x16AC */ f32 minY; // minimum Y value possible for joints, for emulating collision with a floor
/* 0x16B0 */ f32 backPush; // larger values push the cloak further outwards, negative is away from the actor
/* 0x16B4 */ f32 backSwayMagnitude; // magnitude of backwards/forwards swaying
/* 0x16B8 */ f32 sideSwayMagnitude; // magnitude of sideways swaying
/* 0x16BC */ f32 attachRightArmTimer; // timer for the duration of which the cloak is attached to right forearm and left shoulder
/* 0x16C0 */ f32 attachLeftArmTimer; // timer for the duration of which the cloak is attached to left forearm and right shoulder
/* 0x16C4 */ f32 attachShouldersTimer; // timer for the duration of which the cloak is attached to both shoulders
/* 0x16D0 */ f32 minDist; // closest distance the cloak can get to the attached actor without being pushed away
/* 0x1704 */ u8 tearTimer; // tear the cloak for x many frames
void NpcM_GetLimbPositionsForCape(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)

TextLines: // If Launch Level is set, and we're not in that level already, warp there.
// Used on titlescreen for loading extras
// If Launch Level is not set, and debug mode is not on, then get the level
// we're supposed to be in based on current progress and warp there if necessary.
// If Launch Scene is set, then launch that scene.
// This is just some jank so that end of the thonk scene goes to the next courtroom
// scene instead of dumping you back to the scene select in debug mode
// Return to title if CDOWN and START are pressed.
if BUTTON_HELD BTN_CDOWN and BUTTON_HELD BTN_START
// Draw the debug menu and check for selection
// If selection was made, and we're not in the correct level, warp there.
// !!! For levels that don't spawn the controller, SAVE_LAUNCHSCENE must be 0 !!!
Scripts.Name: Init

TextLines: // save the current speaking actor and whether they were set as visibly speaking
// no need to do so if forced present, since the next textbox will be something else anyway
if CONTROLLER_CR_SINGLELIST >= LIST_EVIDENCE and CONTROLLER_CR_SINGLELIST <= LIST_PROFILES
// wait for court record to be closed
// if presenting, the scene has to do something new, so skip restoring old data to scene
// Trigger scene to show the message that was being shown before the cr was opened (it also restores the position)
// if actor was set to be visibly speaking, restore that (in case we're in a multi-textbox message)
// Fix weird bug with responses I can't figure out
Scripts.Name: CourtRecord

TextLines: // reload last save in case stuff changed mid-scene
// player can (for now~) only lose in the court scene so that's where we were
Scripts.Name: Fail

TextLines: // Secret: If UP UP DOWN DOWN LEFT RIGHT LEFT RIGHT B is pressed while Dragmire is shown on screen,
Scripts.Name: Secret

TextLines: // Tween between the defence and prosecutor cameras
// It works, but dunno if we actually want to do that
if CONTROLLER_CAM_PREV == CAMERA_DEFENCE and CONTROLLER_CAM == CAMERA_PROSECUTOR
elif CONTROLLER_CAM_PREV == CAMERA_PROSECUTOR and CONTROLLER_CAM == CAMERA_DEFENCE
Scripts.Name: Camera

TextLines: // This is so that the message currently on screen has time to get logged if
// the msglog is opened quickly enough
// save the current speaking actor and whether they were set as visibly speaking
// trigger scene to show the message that was being shown before the log was opened (it also restores the position)
// Fix weird bug with responses I can't figure out
Scripts.Name: MsgLog

void NpcM_DetectSlowdown(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float slowdownRate)
// If update rate has been set below 3, set it to 3.
// Check if the cycle count since last frame exceeds treshhold.
// If that's been happening for 10 frames, game is slowing down.
// Set the current camera as slow camera and set update rate lower.
// If the camera has been changed, or the last 40 frames have been above the
// slowdown treshhold, return update rate back up.
// Note: This doesn't mean the game is running OK yet - it might get undone once
// the update rate is back up to normal.
// SLOWDOWN_DETECTED variable only gets unset if the camera changed since last time.
// This is so that objects that have been culled out don't appear again -
// which might be what was keeping the framerate low in the first place.
cur->eye.x = Interpolate(ThonkZoomStartPoints[0], ThonkZoomEndPoints[0], THONK_ZOOM_FRAMES, TweenFrameCamera, EASING_TYPE_EASE_IN);
cur->eye.y = Interpolate(ThonkZoomStartPoints[1], ThonkZoomEndPoints[1], THONK_ZOOM_FRAMES, TweenFrameCamera, EASING_TYPE_EASE_IN);
cur->eye.z = Interpolate(ThonkZoomStartPoints[2], ThonkZoomEndPoints[2], THONK_ZOOM_FRAMES, TweenFrameCamera, EASING_TYPE_EASE_IN);
cur->fov = Interpolate(ThonkZoomStartPoints[3], ThonkZoomEndPoints[3], THONK_ZOOM_FRAMES, TweenFrameCamera, EASING_TYPE_EASE_IN);
float NpcM_SwitchCameraBetween(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float dir)
tweened->actor.world.pos.x = Interpolate(TWEEN_STARTPOS.x, TWEEN_X, TWEEN_FRAMES, TWEEN_CURFRAME, TWEEN_EASETYPE);
tweened->actor.world.pos.z = Interpolate(TWEEN_STARTPOS.z, TWEEN_Z, TWEEN_FRAMES, TWEEN_CURFRAME, TWEEN_EASETYPE);
tweened->actor.shape.rot.y = Interpolate(TWEEN_STARTROT, TWEEN_R, TWEEN_FRAMES, TWEEN_CURFRAME, TWEEN_EASETYPE);
void NpcM_SetUpdateRate(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float updateRate)

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
For "post limb" functions, the signature is the same, but some of the arguments might be NULL, and the function doesn't return anything.
For "Skin" models, only the limb number is available.
For others, everything but the translation is available.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
For "post limb" functions, the signature is the same, but some of the arguments might be NULL, and the function doesn't return anything.
For "Skin" models, only the limb number is available.
For others, everything but the translation is available.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
int NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure
void NpcM_PlayRupeeSFXTransposed(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float TransposeNo)

This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.

Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure
if (ret == RESULT_NO_PAK || ret == RESULT_PAK_CHANGED || ret == RESULT_ERR)

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure

MessageTextLines: Hrmm...!<PAUSE:5> Now, this is quite the pickle,
The prosecution has brought up some
good points...<PAUSE:5><SOUND:HINT> but so has the defence.

Messages.Name: JUDGE65
MessageTextLines: Furthermore, we seem to be out of
testimony to discuss, at this point.<PAUSE:5>
<SOUND:CLUE>This will be a hard decision to make...

Messages.Name: LINK120
MessageTextLines: There was something you kept bringing
up in your testimony, Mr.<EMDASH><PAUSE:5> er,<PAUSE:5><SOUND:HINT> witness.

Messages.Name: LINK130
MessageTextLines: You often mentioned that Koholint is
like a dream...<PAUSE:5> or a nightmare.

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE200
MessageTextLines: <SOUND:EXPLOSION>What are you going on about now?!<PAUSE:5>

Messages.Name: OWL120
MessageTextLines: I thought that point was clear.<PAUSE:5>

Messages.Name: OWL130
MessageTextLines: <SOUND:CLUE>We are in a dream right now, too,

Messages.Name: JUDGE70
MessageTextLines: Oh my!<PAUSE:5> This whole trial isn't real?!

Messages.Name: LINK160
MessageTextLines: that clear, I'm just going to go and...<PAUSE:5>

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE220
MessageTextLines: <PAUSE:5>...Why, that might be the wisest thing

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE230
MessageTextLines: But, of course, it's not going to be
YOU waking up.<PAUSE:5><SOUND:WHAP><DI> I'm the only real

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE235
MessageTextLines: I haven't the slightest idea how my
Shouldn't have had that Noble Pursuit

Messages.Name: JUDGE80
MessageTextLines: Ho, ho!<PAUSE:5> I suppose it wouldn't be the
first time I've dreamt of the courtroom!

Messages.Name: JUDGE90
MessageTextLines: It's never been quite this vivid, but I
guess this old man still has quite the

Messages.Name: LINK175
MessageTextLines: a bit OVERactive right now, I guess.<PAUSE:5>
And I haven't even had any Noble

Messages.Name: KOHOLINK50
MessageTextLines: You can't...<PAUSE:5> you can't just wake up!<PAUSE:5>

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE240
MessageTextLines: an invention of my mind, brat!

Messages.Name: JUDGE100
MessageTextLines: I refuse to hand down a faulty verdict!<PAUSE:5>

Messages.Name: JUDGE110
MessageTextLines: No, no, this won't do.<PAUSE:5> I will just have to

Messages.Name: OWL140
MessageTextLines: I have said that this is a dream, yes...<PAUSE:5>
But why would that mean that nothing

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE270
MessageTextLines: Oh, be quiet, you pile of feathers!<PAUSE:5>

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE280
MessageTextLines: Am I stuck in this nightmare?!

Messages.Name: OWL150
MessageTextLines: Hmm.<PAUSE:5> Well, naturally, only one person
here can actually control the dream.

Messages.Name: OWL160
MessageTextLines: <SOUND:HINT>Everyone else is just along for the ride,<PAUSE:5>

Messages.Name: LINK190
MessageTextLines: actually real, just sharing the same

Messages.Name: OWL180
MessageTextLines: Her Grace chose one person to be
the host,<PAUSE:5> and then thrust the others

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE290
MessageTextLines: If this is all in the $$$$$ brat's dream,
why doesn't he just remove his curse

Messages.Name: OWL190
MessageTextLines: Not at all, my angry Gerudo friend.
I never said he's the one in charge.
He came from the dream world of

Messages.Name: DRAGMIRE295
MessageTextLines: <SOUND:EXPLOSION>Well, how did he wind up in someone

Messages.Name: OWL200
MessageTextLines: he is of<SOUND:CLUE> particular interest to the Demon

Messages.Name: OWL210
MessageTextLines: The evil one saw an opportunity,<PAUSE:5> and
forcefully shoved him into the dream
A dreamscape he has been steadily
perverting with his evil for many years.
<SOUND:CLUE>He infested it with his own creations,
twisted it into a dangerous place, and
<PAUSE:5>As a result...<PAUSE:5> that is also why our

Messages.Name: OWL215
MessageTextLines: But...<PAUSE:5> this world is free of <R>Ganon<W>.
Whoever the host of this dream is<PAUSE:5>
Hylia would be very thrilled with that
conclusion,<PAUSE:5><SOUND:ClUE> having made all that effort
to bring her chosen hero here.

Messages.Name: OWL220
MessageTextLines: <SOUND:CLUE>I myself am part of the Wind Fish's spirit.

Messages.Name: OWL230
MessageTextLines: <SOUND:CLUE>I could not just stand idly by when
Hylia's own champion was dealt such
And so,<PAUSE:5> I've tried to lead you to the
eight instruments...<PAUSE:5> and I reached out
to Hylia for help with this predicament.

Messages.Name: LINK200
MessageTextLines: <C>(This is... I can hardly believe it...)

Messages.Name: LINK220
MessageTextLines: <SOUND:DON><SPEED:103>Who is the one controlling this dream?<SPEED:102>

Messages.Name: OWL260
MessageTextLines: <SPEED:101>That is something you'll have to find
<SPEED:101>Whoever it is...<PAUSE:5> will have the final word

Messages.Name: LINK230
MessageTextLines: <C>(So that's it, then...<PAUSE:5> It all hinges
I must consider all the facts!)<SQUARE>

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus:
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
int NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure
// Cursed code to switch actor order to ensure this one processed FIRST
// (So the 2d bg always appears under everything)
PreRender_SetValuesSave(&that->pre, SCREEN_WIDTH, SCREEN_HEIGHT, that->frameBuf2, NULL, that->cvgBuf);
void SetFramebuffer(PlayState* play, Gfx** gfxP, u16* buf)
// The divot filter is applied row-by-row as it only needs to use pixels that are horizontally adjacent
// Decompose each pixel into color channels
// Apply the divot filter itself. For pixels with partial coverage, the filter selects the median value from a
// window of 3 pixels in a horizontal row and uses that as the value for the center pixel.
for (s32 xx = x - 1; xx <= x + 1; xx++)
// White rectangle or else the texture looks too dark
Draw2DInternal(RGBA16, (u8*)that->frameBuf2, NULL, &gfx, SCREEN_WIDTH / 2, SCREEN_HEIGHT / 2, SCREEN_WIDTH, SCREEN_HEIGHT, SCREEN_WIDTH, SCREEN_HEIGHT, 255);
// White rectangle or else the texture looks too dark
Draw2D(RGBA16, OBJECT, play, &gfx, SCREEN_WIDTH / 2, SCREEN_HEIGHT / 2, 0, 0, SCREEN_WIDTH, SCREEN_HEIGHT, 255);
To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure
for (int i = 0; i < SCREEN_WIDTH * SCREEN_HEIGHT / 2; i += 100)

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.

// Determine the strength of that hand (this value is only
// comparable with other hands *of the same type*)
// Strength is just the value of the card there are 5 of
// "0x00000041", where "4" is the value of the card
// there are 4 of, and "1" is the value of the card
// "0x00000311": there are two "1" cards now, and the
// stronger of them needs to be on the left. Since we're
// adding cards from weakest to strongest, that's pretty
// easy to do with some bit-shifting
// Finally, return the *overall* strength value, including the hand type.
// Strength value is at most 20 bits (for HAND_NOTHING),
// so to put the hand type to the left of that, shift by 20

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
For "post limb" functions, the signature is the same, but some of the arguments might be NULL, and the function doesn't return anything.
For "Skin" models, only the limb number is available.
For others, everything but the translation is available.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure

CodeLines: To make NPC Maker able to use your function, it must have the following form:
1. Its name must have a NpcM_ prefix (eg. NpcM_Function),
2. Must have at least two parameters: NpcMaker* and PlayState*. Up to 8 additional float arguments can be passed on from scripts.
3. If you plan to pass the result to scripts, the return type must be float
Examples of valid function signatures are thus, for example:
void NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* play, float argument, float argument1)
The exception for this is functions which should run "On limb", their signature is as follows:
float NpcM_Function(NpcMaker* npc, PlayState* playState, s32 limbNumber, Gfx** dListPtr, Vec3f* translation, Vec3s* rotation, void* instance, Gfx** gfxP)
This function should return 0 if the limb is meant to be drawn, and 1 if it is not.
For "post limb" functions, the signature is the same, but some of the arguments might be NULL, and the function doesn't return anything.
For "Skin" models, only the limb number is available.
For others, everything but the translation is available.
Warning; When using these functions from scripts, make sure
// Count the number of scenes that will be shown...
